summary: This document contains a series of correspondence from Capital One Services, LLC to Phillip I. Williams regarding his secured MasterCard account. It includes notices of a returned payment, policy changes about security deposits, and a past-due payment reminder. The documents appear to be routine financial account communications.

persons.name: Phillip I. Williams
persons.context: The individual who holds a Capital One secured MasterCard account, receiving communications about a returned payment, policy changes, and a past-due balance.

events.title: Returned Payment
events.description: A $50.00 pay-by-phone payment from Phillip I. Williams to Capital One was returned by his financial institution due to an invalid account number.

events.title: Policy Change on Security Deposits
events.description: Capital One notified Phillip I. Williams that, as of this date, the option to make additional security deposits to increase the credit limit on his secured MasterCard would be discontinued.

events.title: Second Policy Change Notice
events.description: Capital One sent a second notice to Phillip I. Williams reiterating the discontinuation of the option to make additional security deposits to increase his credit limit, effective this date.

events.title: Past-Due Payment Deadline
events.description: The due date for a minimum payment of $108.00 to bring Phillip I. Williams's account, with a balance of $269.81, up to date.

locations: P.O. Box 30278 Salt Lake City, UT 84130.0278
P.O. Box 30285 Salt Lake City, UT 841300285
keyFacts: Phillip I. Williams had a secured MasterCard account with Capital One that experienced a returned payment in July 2015.
Capital One changed its policy, discontinuing the option for account holders to add security deposits to increase their credit limits, with notices sent in 2015 and 2016.
By July 2016, Phillip I. Williams's account was past due with a balance of $269.81 and a minimum payment of $108.00 due.
The correspondence includes standard legal disclosures related to debt collection and consumer rights across various states.
The document appears to be routine financial account management correspondence with no direct, explicit connection to the broader Epstein case narrative.
